posts.name: Alex Yavorskiy
posts.cooked:
This approach is used in Wire Messenger demo docker images, you can take a look https://github.com/wireapp/wire-server/blob/develop/deploy/docker-ephemeral/docker-compose.yaml#L29
They use https://github.com/minio/minio for fake S3, in case of Signal you will need to modify source code to use ‘localhost’ instead of production AWS S3 links

posts.cooked:
megatron:

replace the amazon s3 stack

As mentioned by Aleksey, the usual suggestion is minio, if you are wanting a self-hosted or private-system way to run your own signal4server node without the amazon dependency.

  • in use (with signal-server?) back in March 2017, https://community.signalusers.org/t/use-minio-for-storing-attachments/832
  • suggested use-case from August 2018, https://community.signalusers.org/t/signal-fork-self-hosted-signal-interested/3808/2
  • and as of the last couple months, there is a group working in Florida+India that is using minio with their custom signal4server, as well, https://community.signalusers.org/t/message-retrieval-for-all-my-app-users/5451 and https://community.signalusers.org/t/need-help-to-retrieve-data-from-db/5448 plus https://community.signalusers.org/t/ios-app-build-help-needed/5008

In addition to minio as linked above (codebase is GoLang, Apache2 license, 2014+ silicon valley startup, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minio), you might also want to look into these options… “A list of S3-compatible storage solutions” == http://www.s3-client.com/s3-compatible-storage-solutions.html

  • https://github.com/ceph/ceph , C++ codebase, LGPLv21, 2006+ RedHat&CentOS Linux project, https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_ceph_storage/3/html/developer_guide/ceph-object-gateway-s3-api and details at https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_ceph_storage/3/ , plus https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceph_(software)
  • https://github.com/openstack/swift , python codebase, Apache2 license, 2010+ Rackspace project, https://docs.openstack.org/newton/config-reference/object-storage/configure-s3.html , https://docs.openstack.org/swift/rocky/middleware.html , plus maybe https://github.com/javaswift/joss , difficult to setup in some ways but does have swift-in-a-VM, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenStack#Object_storage_(Swift)
  • https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus , Java and C codebase, GPLv3 + proprietary dual-licensing (same as signalapp), 2008+ project by HP-slash-DXC which was reverse-forked in late 2017 (by AppScale), https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eucalyptus_(software)
  • https://github.com/basho/riak , Erlang, freemium (partly Apache2 license), 2009+ by former SalesForce & Akamai folks (Basho Tech), https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riak
  • https://github.com/leo-project/leofs , Erlang codebase methinks , might be Apache2 license, has some support from Rakuten-slash-Alibaba, no wikipedia article

There is another website that mentions, in tip#8, four of the five projects above, as well as a couple more local-testing-type simplistic options:

  • S3Proxy, https://github.com/gaul/s3proxy , Java codebase, https://gaul.org/talks/introduction-to-s3proxy-and-swiftproxy.pdf , no wikipedia article
  • FakeS3, https://rubygems.org/gems/fakes3 , Ruby codebase, https://github.com/jubos/fake-s3 , plus https://findnerd.com/list/view/Fake-S3-Server-For-Local-Development-in-Rails/21445 , no wikipedia article

Finally, worth mentioning that there are already various other S3-based projects out there, which sometimes have discussions about supporting Minio/Ceph/etc, see this for example == https://github.com/sonatype/nexus-blobstore-s3/issues/2

posts.name: Kondal Rao
posts.cooked:
Is it sorted out guys…Will only changing the sample.yml file with the Minio credentials work? or need to add more modifications?

For yours info I am working with android version 4.25.10 and server version v1.88 (both are custom compiled at my end)

thanks in advance.

Pointing to custom server from android client

to implement the Minio as the object storage purpose.

What I did so far for integrating Minio is the following:

  1. I have installed Minio in my ubuntu server environment. version:
Version: 2019-06-04T01:15:58Z
Release-Tag: RELEASE.2019-06-04T01-15-58Z
Commit-ID: ff7799452bf95b0706194896278aef7cc8034076
  1. When I run the minio server I got something like below:
Endpoint:  http://192.168.X.XX:9000  http://172.17.X.X:9000  http://127.0.X.X:9000
AccessKey: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
SecretKey: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
Region:    us-east-1

Browser Access:
   http://192.168.X.XX:9000  http://172.XX.0.1:9000  http://127.0.0.1:9000

Command-line Access: https://docs.minio.io/docs/minio-client-quickstart-guide
   $ mc config host add myminio http://192.168.X.XX:9000 XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

Object API (Amazon S3 compatible):
   Go:         https://docs.minio.io/docs/golang-client-quickstart-guide
   Java:       https://docs.minio.io/docs/java-client-quickstart-guide
   Python:     https://docs.minio.io/docs/python-client-quickstart-guide
   JavaScript: https://docs.minio.io/docs/javascript-client-quickstart-guide
   .NET:       https://docs.minio.io/docs/dotnet-client-quickstart-guide

So from the browser I was able to run the minio interface, then by providing the accesskey and secretkey input value from the above, I suceessfully logged in into my Minio account to check whether something has been uploaded or not.

Now Manually I created the bucket name as for say “bucket-xx-for-profile” and “bucket-yy-for-attachments” ( one for profile picture related upload and another one for the attachemnets to be uploaded)

  1. Now I have used these accessKey, secretKey and Region values from the above into my sample.yml file like below:
attachments: # AWS S3 configuration
  accessKey: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
  accessSecret: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
  bucket: bucket-yy-for-attachments

profiles: # AWS S3 configuration
  accessKey: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
  accessSecret: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
  bucket: bucket-xx-for-profile
  region: us-east-1

These are all I did. What else I need to do, could you please help if some code needs to be added or not. I have searched over the discussion forum a lot, but could not found any solid step wise info

There are at least three approaches here, that you can possibly utilize:

  1. you can modify the etc hosts file on your custom signal-server node, and redirect outbound traffic that is going from your machine to *.s3-accelerate.amazonaws.com to instead go to localhost:9000 aka your minio server (not confirmed to work however so you will have to try it and troubleshoot a little). Equivalently, you can setup some other kind of network-layer redirection magic, so that although signal-server is “trying” to connect with S3 it ends up actually connecting with your port 9000 of your minio installation. This is a bit brittle though

  2. you can modify the signal-server codebase, finding all the places where it utilizes S3 to setup a connection…

  • import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentials;
  • import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentialsProvider;
  • import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSStaticCredentialsProvider;
  • import com.amazonaws.auth.BasicAWSCredentials;
  • import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3;
  • import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3Client;

which for starters is Code search results · GitHub … and then modify that code to look more like this:

    AmazonS3 s3Client = new AmazonS3Client( ... );
    s3Client.setEndpoint("https://localhost:9000");

link, link2, link3, link4differentAPI… which will override the default upstream URL of S3 more properly than the network trick outlined in option#1. (Assumes you have configured LetsEncrypt for your minio install… might be able to use http:// if you are really just on localhost however)

Ideally, you would go a bit further, and modify the YML so that you were able to specify the “S3”-endpoint next to the accessSecret and other things already mentioned there, so that you don’t have to hardcode your ‘localhost:9000’ stuff everywhere :-)

  1. if you are unable to get the basic hosts-file trick to work, and unable to modify your signal-server codebase properly, there are probably some more Rube Goldberg style tricks we can try. But I would go with option#1 for now, and option#2 if you have time to do things properly. Do you have your signal-server code in github yet? I can take a look there and see what v1.88 uses in the AWS portions

posts.name: Kondal Rao
posts.cooked:
Just want to mention that when I was using the hand compiled old server ( probably version 1.26) and hand compiled client code on that code I successfully configured Minio server connection. On that time I had to make the following changes in the UrlSigner.java file under package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.util;


package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.util;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException;
import javax.management.openmbean.InvalidKeyException;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.configuration.S3Configuration;
import org.xmlpull.v1.XmlPullParserException;
import com.amazonaws.HttpMethod;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.auth.BasicAWSCredentials;
import io.minio.MinioClient;
import io.minio.errors.MinioException;

public class UrlSigner {

	private static final Integer DURATION = 60 * 60 * 24;

	@SuppressWarnings("unused")
	private final AWSCredentials credentials;
	private final String bucket;

	public UrlSigner(S3Configuration config) {
		this.credentials = new BasicAWSCredentials(config.getAccessKey(), config.getAccessSecret());
		this.bucket = config.getAttachmentsBucket();
	}

	public String getPreSignedUrl(long attachmentId, HttpMethod method)
			throws InvalidKeyException, NoSuchAlgorithmException, IOException, XmlPullParserException, MinioException {
		String request = geturl(bucket, String.valueOf(attachmentId), method);
		return request;
	}
	
	public String geturl(String bucketname, String attachemtnId, HttpMethod method)
			throws NoSuchAlgorithmException, IOException, InvalidKeyException, XmlPullParserException, MinioException {
		String url = null;

		MinioClient minioClient = new MinioClient("http://abc.xxx.com:9000", "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX","XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX");

		try {

			if (!minioClient.bucketExists(bucketname)) {
				minioClient.makeBucket("signalbucket1234","us-east-1");
			} 

			if (method == HttpMethod.PUT) {
				url = minioClient.presignedPutObject("signalbucket1234", attachemtnId, DURATION);
			}
			if (method == HttpMethod.GET) {
				url = minioClient.presignedGetObject("signalbucket1234", attachemtnId);
			}
		} catch (MinioException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		} catch (java.security.InvalidKeyException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		}

		return url;
	}

}

Other than this I changed the sample.yml file with the Minio Credentials in the following way:

s3: # AWS S3 configuration
   accessKey: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
   accessSecret: XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
   attachmentsBucket: signalbucket1234

So now in the version 1.88 I found the UrlSigner file in the following way:

package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3;

import com.amazonaws.HttpMethod;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.auth.BasicAWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3Client;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.S3ClientOptions;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.GeneratePresignedUrlRequest;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.configuration.AttachmentsConfiguration;

import java.net.URL;
import java.util.Date;

public class UrlSigner {

  private static final long   DURATION = 60 * 60 * 1000;

  private final AWSCredentials credentials;
  private final String bucket;

  public UrlSigner(AttachmentsConfiguration config) {
    this.credentials = new BasicAWSCredentials(config.getAccessKey(), config.getAccessSecret());
    this.bucket      = config.getBucket();
  }

  public URL getPreSignedUrl(long attachmentId, HttpMethod method, boolean unaccelerated) {
    AmazonS3                    client  = new AmazonS3Client(credentials);
    GeneratePresignedUrlRequest request = new GeneratePresignedUrlRequest(bucket, String.valueOf(attachmentId), method);
    
    request.setExpiration(new Date(System.currentTimeMillis() + DURATION));
    request.setContentType("application/octet-stream");

    if (unaccelerated) {
      client.setS3ClientOptions(S3ClientOptions.builder().setPathStyleAccess(true).build());
    } else {
      client.setS3ClientOptions(S3ClientOptions.builder().setAccelerateModeEnabled(true).build());
    }

    return client.generatePresignedUrl(request);
  }

}

So now my question is how to change the above new file?

Please help.

posts.name: Kondal Rao
posts.cooked:
I also see that for profile picture upload at the time of user Registration make a call to the v1/profile API which is basically written in this following file

package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.controllers;

import java.security.SecureRandom;
import java.time.ZoneOffset;
import java.time.ZonedDateTime;

import javax.ws.rs.GET;
import javax.ws.rs.PUT;
import javax.ws.rs.Path;
import javax.ws.rs.PathParam;
import javax.ws.rs.Produces;
import javax.ws.rs.QueryParam;
import javax.ws.rs.WebApplicationException;
import javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType;
import javax.ws.rs.core.Response;

import org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Base64;
import org.hibernate.validator.constraints.Length;
import org.hibernate.validator.valuehandling.UnwrapValidatedValue;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.configuration.ProfilesConfiguration;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.entities.Profile;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.entities.ProfileAvatarUploadAttributes;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.limits.RateLimiters;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3.PolicySigner;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3.PostPolicyGenerator;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.storage.Account;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.storage.AccountsManager;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.util.Pair;

import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentialsProvider;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSStaticCredentialsProvider;
import com.amazonaws.auth.BasicAWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3Client;
import com.codahale.metrics.annotation.Timed;
import com.google.common.base.Optional;

import io.dropwizard.auth.Auth;

@Path("/v1/profile")
public class ProfileController {

  private final RateLimiters     rateLimiters;
  private final AccountsManager  accountsManager;

  private final PolicySigner        policySigner;
  private final PostPolicyGenerator policyGenerator;

  private final AmazonS3            s3client;
  private final String              bucket;

  public ProfileController(RateLimiters rateLimiters,
                           AccountsManager accountsManager,
                           ProfilesConfiguration profilesConfiguration)
  {
    AWSCredentials         credentials         = new BasicAWSCredentials(profilesConfiguration.getAccessKey(), profilesConfiguration.getAccessSecret());
    AWSCredentialsProvider credentialsProvider = new AWSStaticCredentialsProvider(credentials);

    this.rateLimiters       = rateLimiters;
    this.accountsManager    = accountsManager;
    this.bucket             = profilesConfiguration.getBucket();
    this.s3client           = AmazonS3Client.builder()
                                            .withCredentials(credentialsProvider)
                                            .withRegion(profilesConfiguration.getRegion())
                                            .build();

    this.policyGenerator  = new PostPolicyGenerator(profilesConfiguration.getRegion(),
                                                    profilesConfiguration.getBucket(),
                                                    profilesConfiguration.getAccessKey());

    this.policySigner     = new PolicySigner(profilesConfiguration.getAccessSecret(),
                                             profilesConfiguration.getRegion());
  }

  @Timed
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/{number}")
  public Profile getProfile(@Auth Account account,
                            @PathParam("number") String number,
                            @QueryParam("ca") boolean useCaCertificate)
      throws RateLimitExceededException
  {
    rateLimiters.getProfileLimiter().validate(account.getNumber());

    Optional<Account> accountProfile = accountsManager.get(number);

    if (!accountProfile.isPresent()) {
      throw new WebApplicationException(Response.status(404).build());
    }

    return new Profile(accountProfile.get().getName(),
                       accountProfile.get().getAvatar(),
                       accountProfile.get().getIdentityKey());
  }

  @Timed
  @PUT
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/name/{name}")
  public void setProfile(@Auth Account account, @PathParam("name") @UnwrapValidatedValue(true) @Length(min = 72,max= 72) Optional<String> name) {
	
    account.setName(name.orNull());
    accountsManager.update(account);
  }


  @Timed
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/form/avatar")
  public ProfileAvatarUploadAttributes getAvatarUploadForm(@Auth Account account) {
    String               previousAvatar = account.getAvatar();
    ZonedDateTime        now            = ZonedDateTime.now(ZoneOffset.UTC);
    String               objectName     = generateAvatarObjectName();
    Pair<String, String> policy         = policyGenerator.createFor(now, objectName);
    String               signature      = policySigner.getSignature(now, policy.second());

    if (previousAvatar != null && previousAvatar.startsWith("profiles/")) {
      s3client.deleteObject(bucket, previousAvatar);
    }

    account.setAvatar(objectName);
    accountsManager.update(account);

    return new ProfileAvatarUploadAttributes(objectName, policy.first(), "private", "AWS4-HMAC-SHA256",
                                             now.format(PostPolicyGenerator.AWS_DATE_TIME), policy.second(), signature);
  }

  private String generateAvatarObjectName() {
    byte[] object = new byte[16];
    new SecureRandom().nextBytes(object);

    return "profiles/" + Base64.encodeBase64URLSafeString(object);
  }
}

I have already defined the profile and attachment related configuration in the sample.yml file, that already I have shared in the above thread.

kondal789rao:

Please HELP!! I am badly stuck. I believe out of so much community members somebody might have saved his attachments and profile image in Minio. Please help me…save me…

I don’t think this has been figured out yet :-) Because you are wanting to modify the server code, rather than doing a network-level redirect with /etc/hosts or similar. That is a better less-brittle approach, but it is also tougher and more difficult to implement the first time around.

In any case, there is no hurry. Just be patient and keep up your spirits, difficult things always take time, especially when done on a volunteer enthusiast basis. Just concentrate on providing detailed information and well-posed questions, and with luck somebody will be able to help you out. No need to implore your fellow enthusiasts for pity ;-)

please don’t mind…sometimes bad students like me need more and more explanation to understand the whole thing…

kondal789rao:

What exactly I need to do in the /etc/hosts file

It is basically the DIY equivalent to a DNS lookup. When you open your browser and you type “www.signal.org” that is a human-readable domain name, but your browser needs the IP address not the domain-name, so it performs a DNS lookup to figure out the answer.

$ dig www.signal.org

; <<>> DiG 9.13.0 <<>> www.signal.org
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 53248
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 4, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 8192
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;www.signal.org.			IN	A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
www.signal.org.		60	IN	A	143.204.158.20
www.signal.org.		60	IN	A	143.204.158.103
www.signal.org.		60	IN	A	143.204.158.97
www.signal.org.		60	IN	A	143.204.158.6

So in theory, you should be able to visit https://143.204.158.20:443/ instead of visiting https://www.signal.org:443 …but in practice you cannot, the HTTP headers will be incorrect and you won’t be able to get to the actual website you are seeking, instead you’ll get stuck in the various layers of indirection.

Nothing is simple nowadays, sorry :-)

When you are using the /etc/hosts file, or the windows equivalent thereof .\etc\hosts file instead, what happens is that the OS notices some entries in the ancient crufty DIY DNS local configuration, and instead of performing a DNS lookup on the internet, performs a textfile lookup right on your own system. If you go into your /etc/hosts and enter the correctly-formatted incantation, you can “trick” the browser into visiting somewhere completely different.

But the hosts file was invented in the very early days of the ARPANET, long before it became the internet in the 1980s, and long before HTTP was invented in the 1990s. This is complaining from 1973 about the ridiculous nature of the HOSTS file and trying to centralize control :-) RFC 606 - Host names on-line and RFC 608 - Host names on-line are fun reading. But they should be read as what they are: attempts to change existing practice rather than a description of that existing practice.

So in order to make your minio function without altering the signal-server code, you will need to alter the way that your signal-server node connects to the internet. You should have already setup a reverse-proxy configuration of a webserver, so that when visitors to port 443 on your system appear, you can use bog-standard SSL certs from LetsEncrypt to keep that safe, and then you can pass along the socket to port 8080 where the jetty inside signal-server is listening for traffic.

Thus, my advice is that you should use the /etc/hosts file to direct outbound traffic that is aimed at amazon servers, to instead go to your own 127.0.0.1 webserver … and then use the webserver’s reverse-proxy configuration file to detect all the S3 stuff, and instead point it to your minio install

posts.name: Kondal Rao
posts.cooked:
Hey @5_c_d sorry, I was out of town for few days so forgot to post the details that made my code work for Minio, following is the code for Minio for uploading attachments and profile image:

  1. provide the minio related values in the cnfig/sample.yml file:
attachments: # AWS S3 configuration
  accessKey: XXXXX-MINIO-ACCESS_KEY-XXXXXX
  accessSecret: XXXXX-MINIO-ACCESS_SECRET-XXXXXX
  bucket: att-bucket

profiles: # AWS S3 configuration
  accessKey: XXXXX-MINIO-ACCESS_KEY-XXXXXX
  accessSecret: XXXXX-MINIO-ACCESS_SECRET-XXXXXX
  bucket: pp-bucket
  region: us-east-1
  1. make the UrlSigner.java file like this beow:

package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.security.InvalidKeyException;
import java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException;

import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.configuration.AttachmentsConfiguration;
import org.xmlpull.v1.XmlPullParserException;

import com.amazonaws.HttpMethod;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.auth.BasicAWSCredentials;

import io.minio.MinioClient;
import io.minio.errors.MinioException;

public class UrlSigner {

  private static final long   DURATION = 60 * 60 * 1000;

  private final AWSCredentials credentials;
  private final String bucket;
  
  public UrlSigner(AttachmentsConfiguration config) {
	    this.credentials = new BasicAWSCredentials(config.getAccessKey(), config.getAccessSecret());
	    this.bucket      = config.getBucket();
	  }

  public String getPreSignedUrl(long attachmentId, HttpMethod method) throws InvalidKeyException, NoSuchAlgorithmException, IOException, XmlPullParserException, MinioException {
  		String request = geturl(bucket, String.valueOf(attachmentId), method);    		
  		return request;
  }

  public String geturl( String bucketname, String attachemtnId, HttpMethod method) throws NoSuchAlgorithmException,
	        IOException, InvalidKeyException, XmlPullParserException, MinioException {	
	    
	    String url = null;
	    
	
	 MinioClient minioClient = new MinioClient("https://abc.xxx.com:9000", "XXXXX-MINIO-ACCESS_KEY-XXXXXX", "XXXXX-MINIO-ACCESS_SECRET-XXXXXX");
	  
	    try {
	    	if(method==HttpMethod.PUT){		    		
	    		url = minioClient.presignedPutObject(bucketname, attachemtnId, 60 * 60 * 24);
	    	}
	    	if(method==HttpMethod.GET){		    		 
	    		url = minioClient.presignedGetObject(bucketname, attachemtnId);
	    	}
	        System.out.println(url);
	    } catch(MinioException e) {
	      System.out.println("Error occurred: " + e);
	    } catch (java.security.InvalidKeyException e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
		}
	
	    return url;
	}

/*  public UrlSigner(AttachmentsConfiguration config) {
    this.credentials = new BasicAWSCredentials(config.getAccessKey(), config.getAccessSecret());
    this.bucket      = config.getBucket();
  }

  public URL getPreSignedUrl(long attachmentId, HttpMethod method, boolean unaccelerated) {
    AmazonS3                    client  = new AmazonS3Client(credentials);
    GeneratePresignedUrlRequest request = new GeneratePresignedUrlRequest(bucket, String.valueOf(attachmentId), method);
    
    request.setExpiration(new Date(System.currentTimeMillis() + DURATION));
    request.setContentType("application/octet-stream");

    if (unaccelerated) {
      client.setS3ClientOptions(S3ClientOptions.builder().setPathStyleAccess(true).build());
    } else {
      client.setS3ClientOptions(S3ClientOptions.builder().setAccelerateModeEnabled(true).build());
    }

    return client.generatePresignedUrl(request);
  }*/

}
  1. AttachmentController.java

package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.controllers;

import com.amazonaws.HttpMethod;
import com.codahale.metrics.annotation.Timed;
import com.google.common.base.Optional;
import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.entities.AttachmentDescriptor;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.entities.AttachmentUri;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.federation.FederatedClientManager;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.federation.NoSuchPeerException;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.limits.RateLimiters;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.storage.Account;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.util.Conversions;
import org.xmlpull.v1.XmlPullParserException;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3.UrlSigner;

import javax.ws.rs.GET;
import javax.ws.rs.Path;
import javax.ws.rs.PathParam;
import javax.ws.rs.Produces;
import javax.ws.rs.QueryParam;
import javax.ws.rs.WebApplicationException;
import javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType;
import javax.ws.rs.core.Response;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.net.URL;
import java.security.InvalidKeyException;
import java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException;
import java.security.SecureRandom;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

import io.dropwizard.auth.Auth;
import io.minio.errors.MinioException;


@Path("/v1/attachments")
public class AttachmentController {

  private final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(AttachmentController.class);

  private static final String[] UNACCELERATED_REGIONS = {"+20", "+971", "+968", "+974"};

  private final RateLimiters           rateLimiters;
  private final FederatedClientManager federatedClientManager;
  private final UrlSigner              urlSigner;

  public AttachmentController(RateLimiters rateLimiters,
                              FederatedClientManager federatedClientManager,
                              UrlSigner urlSigner)
  {
    this.rateLimiters           = rateLimiters;
    this.federatedClientManager = federatedClientManager;
    this.urlSigner              = urlSigner;
  }

  @Timed
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  public AttachmentDescriptor allocateAttachment(@Auth Account account)
      throws RateLimitExceededException, InvalidKeyException, NoSuchAlgorithmException, IOException, XmlPullParserException, MinioException
  {
    if (account.isRateLimited()) {
      rateLimiters.getAttachmentLimiter().validate(account.getNumber());
    }

    long attachmentId = generateAttachmentId();
    //URL  url          = urlSigner.getPreSignedUrl(attachmentId, HttpMethod.PUT, Stream.of(UNACCELERATED_REGIONS).anyMatch(region -> account.getNumber().startsWith(region)));
    String  url          = urlSigner.getPreSignedUrl(attachmentId, HttpMethod.PUT);

    //return new AttachmentDescriptor(attachmentId, url.toExternalForm());
    return new AttachmentDescriptor(attachmentId, url);

  }

  @Timed
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/{attachmentId}")
  public AttachmentUri redirectToAttachment(@Auth                      Account account,
                                            @PathParam("attachmentId") long    attachmentId,
                                            @QueryParam("relay")       Optional<String> relay)
      throws IOException, InvalidKeyException, NoSuchAlgorithmException, XmlPullParserException, MinioException
  {
    try {
      if (!relay.isPresent()) {
        //return new AttachmentUri(urlSigner.getPreSignedUrl(attachmentId, HttpMethod.GET, Stream.of(UNACCELERATED_REGIONS).anyMatch(region -> account.getNumber().startsWith(region))));
        return new AttachmentUri(new URL(urlSigner.getPreSignedUrl(attachmentId, HttpMethod.GET)));
      } else {
        return new AttachmentUri(federatedClientManager.getClient(relay.get()).getSignedAttachmentUri(attachmentId));
      }
    } catch (NoSuchPeerException e) {
      logger.info("No such peer: " + relay);
      throw new WebApplicationException(Response.status(404).build());
    }
  }

  private long generateAttachmentId() {
    byte[] attachmentBytes = new byte[8];
    new SecureRandom().nextBytes(attachmentBytes);

    attachmentBytes[0] = (byte)(attachmentBytes[0] & 0x7F);
    return Conversions.byteArrayToLong(attachmentBytes);
  }
}
  1. ProfileController.java
package org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.controllers;

import java.security.SecureRandom;
import java.time.ZoneOffset;
import java.time.ZonedDateTime;

import javax.ws.rs.GET;
import javax.ws.rs.PUT;
import javax.ws.rs.Path;
import javax.ws.rs.PathParam;
import javax.ws.rs.Produces;
import javax.ws.rs.QueryParam;
import javax.ws.rs.WebApplicationException;
import javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType;
import javax.ws.rs.core.Response;

import org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Base64;
import org.hibernate.validator.constraints.Length;
import org.hibernate.validator.valuehandling.UnwrapValidatedValue;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.configuration.ProfilesConfiguration;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.entities.Profile;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.entities.ProfileAvatarUploadAttributes;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.limits.RateLimiters;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3.PolicySigner;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.s3.PostPolicyGenerator;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.storage.Account;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.storage.AccountsManager;
import org.whispersystems.textsecuregcm.util.Pair;

import com.amazonaws.ClientConfiguration;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSCredentialsProvider;
import io.minio.MinioClient;
import io.minio.errors.MinioException;
import com.amazonaws.auth.AWSStaticCredentialsProvider;
import com.amazonaws.auth.BasicAWSCredentials;
import com.amazonaws.client.builder.AwsClientBuilder;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3Client;
import com.amazonaws.services.s3.AmazonS3ClientBuilder;
import com.codahale.metrics.annotation.Timed;
import com.google.common.base.Optional;

import io.dropwizard.auth.Auth;

@Path("/v1/profile")
public class ProfileController {

  private final RateLimiters     rateLimiters;
  private final AccountsManager  accountsManager;

  private final PolicySigner        policySigner;
  private final PostPolicyGenerator policyGenerator;

  private final AmazonS3            s3client;
  private final String              bucket;

  public ProfileController(RateLimiters rateLimiters,
                           AccountsManager accountsManager,
                           ProfilesConfiguration profilesConfiguration)
  {
    AWSCredentials         credentials         = new BasicAWSCredentials(profilesConfiguration.getAccessKey(), profilesConfiguration.getAccessSecret());
    AWSCredentialsProvider credentialsProvider = new AWSStaticCredentialsProvider(credentials);

    this.rateLimiters       = rateLimiters;
    this.accountsManager    = accountsManager;
    this.bucket             = profilesConfiguration.getBucket();
/*    this.s3client           = AmazonS3Client.builder()
                                            .withCredentials(credentialsProvider)
                                            .withRegion(profilesConfiguration.getRegion())
                                            .build();*/

    ClientConfiguration clientConfiguration = new ClientConfiguration();
    clientConfiguration.setSignerOverride("AWSS3V4SignerType");
    
    this.s3client           = AmazonS3ClientBuilder
										    .standard()
										    .withEndpointConfiguration(new AwsClientBuilder.EndpointConfiguration("https://abc.xxx.com:9000", "us-east-1"))
										    .withPathStyleAccessEnabled(true)
										    .withClientConfiguration(clientConfiguration)
										    .withCredentials(new AWSStaticCredentialsProvider(credentials))
										    .build();

    this.policyGenerator  = new PostPolicyGenerator(profilesConfiguration.getRegion(),
                                                    profilesConfiguration.getBucket(),
                                                    profilesConfiguration.getAccessKey());

    this.policySigner     = new PolicySigner(profilesConfiguration.getAccessSecret(),
                                             profilesConfiguration.getRegion());
  }

  @Timed
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/{number}")
  public Profile getProfile(@Auth Account account,
                            @PathParam("number") String number,
                            @QueryParam("ca") boolean useCaCertificate)
      throws RateLimitExceededException
  {
    rateLimiters.getProfileLimiter().validate(account.getNumber());

    Optional<Account> accountProfile = accountsManager.get(number);

    if (!accountProfile.isPresent()) {
      throw new WebApplicationException(Response.status(404).build());
    }

    return new Profile(accountProfile.get().getName(),
                       accountProfile.get().getAvatar(),
                       accountProfile.get().getIdentityKey());
  }

  @Timed
  @PUT
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/name/{name}")
  public void setProfile(@Auth Account account, @PathParam("name") @UnwrapValidatedValue(true) @Length(min = 72,max= 72) Optional<String> name) {
    account.setName(name.orNull());
    accountsManager.update(account);
  }


  @Timed
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
  @Path("/form/avatar")
  public ProfileAvatarUploadAttributes getAvatarUploadForm(@Auth Account account) {
    String               previousAvatar = account.getAvatar();
    ZonedDateTime        now            = ZonedDateTime.now(ZoneOffset.UTC);
    String               objectName     = generateAvatarObjectName();
    Pair<String, String> policy         = policyGenerator.createFor(now, objectName);
    String               signature      = policySigner.getSignature(now, policy.second());

    if (previousAvatar != null && previousAvatar.startsWith("profiles/")) {
      s3client.deleteObject(bucket, previousAvatar);
    }

    account.setAvatar(objectName);
    accountsManager.update(account);

    return new ProfileAvatarUploadAttributes(objectName, policy.first(), "private", "AWS4-HMAC-SHA256",
                                             now.format(PostPolicyGenerator.AWS_DATE_TIME), policy.second(), signature);
  }

  private String generateAvatarObjectName() {
    byte[] object = new byte[16];
    new SecureRandom().nextBytes(object);

    return "profiles/" + Base64.encodeBase64URLSafeString(object);
  }
}

That is all. I hope from now onwards, doubts about integration of minio as a replacement for AWS should be cleared. This code worked for me. I would like to suggest that please see the commented out codes also clearly in my code files.
Nice, thank you kindly. @omkarpise does this approach do what you are wanting? Can you see any ways to improve it?
